body:
> judeo christian

Stop slipping Jews into Christianity 

But other than that Christianity has been externally beneficial for western society, allowing for an objective morality and allowed for the creation of high trust societies.

Without it we would be stuck in the Bronze Age with either Muslims or Chinese being the major power 

The USA was the most based between the late 1800s and the early 1900s

To say it holds back conservatism is forgetting the fact it holds together conservatism.

body: I was actually hoping you'd comment here. I agree with you 100% that Christianity has gotten us to where we are today, but I do not think it can get us any farther. The reason being is that as an irreligious person I still hold 99.999% of the values of a right wing conservative without the vagueness and interpretation of religion. I think the bible itself was a very good rule book, maybe the best ever written. I think though that it should be built upon rather than taken as the alpha and the omega. I think that religion is used against the right as a muzzle and due to the nature of interpretation will be used as a way to push progressivism into conservatism.

The question you are asking will inevitably lead to a very basic and fundemental question: Do you believe in Christ God?

For me, I believe in Christ and that the Orthodox Church is his one true church.

With that said, now I can say that Christ is the only immutable foundation of morality. All other attempts at it, whether it's secular, political, or philosophical, quickly enter on a slippery slope of subjective morality.

body: Actual historians. Gay stuff existed LONG before Rome. The Romans were actually the first major society to start hating it. The only thing they considered acceptable was banging a male slave, and you had to be a top. There is even evidence that it was punishable by death. On the other hand the evidence for early Christians believing this is slim to none. There is in fact a bit to the contrary, including that the first gentile convert was asking for his "boy" to be healed. And there is a strong possibility that David and Jonathan's "covenant" was a little more than just being "really good friends", especially considering how Saul reacted and the romantic comments. And if this were an issue for Israel and Judah back then, it would've been edited out because these books generally try to portray the patriarchs as positively as possible.

parent.body: Actual historians. Gay stuff existed LONG before Rome. The Romans were actually the first major society to start hating it. The only thing they considered acceptable was banging a male slave, and you had to be a top. There is even evidence that it was punishable by death. On the other hand the evidence for early Christians believing this is slim to none. There is in fact a bit to the contrary, including that the first gentile convert was asking for his "boy" to be healed. And there is a strong possibility that David and Jonathan's "covenant" was a little more than just being "really good friends", especially considering how Saul reacted and the romantic comments. And if this were an issue for Israel and Judah back then, it would've been edited out because these books generally try to portray the patriarchs as positively as possible.

Most, if not all, of what conservatism is trying to conserve has been given to us by religion.

body:
Just to be clear, are you saying Christianity is incompatible with any authoritarian state, or just a secular one? The latter cracks down on Christianity because Christianity is *the other*, it doesn't belong, and it threatens the way things are with it's stubborn insistence upon it's convictions. The incompatibility (or at least potential conflict) is visible clear as day. But that doesn't mean Christianity is inherently libertarian. After all, what about the authoritarian states that embrace Christianity? They don't really have much cause for crackdowns, do they?

The only way an authoritarian state would be incompatible with Christianity is if Christianity by it's definition rejected it. But I'm not sure it does.

The fact that Israelites weren't supposed to have a king is relevant, but it's not like the laws of the book of Deuteronomy, which the Israelites were supposed to follow even before then, were exactly libertarian. It just wasn't the king who enforced them.

>"A woman shall not wear a man's garment, nor shall a man put on a woman's cloak, for whoever does these things is an abomination to the Lord your God." - Deuteronomy 22:5, (English Standard Version translation of the Bible)

body:
> After all, what about the authoritarian states that embrace Christianity?

Don't blindly believe everything labeled "Christian". Every time there's any kind of spiritual awakening, a religious counterpart will arise to get people in line again. The Israelites did it, then the Jews did it, then Rome did it, then Islam did it, then the Protestants did it. It happens every single time.

> The fact that Israelites weren't supposed to have a king is relevant, but it's not like the laws of the book of Deuteronomy, which the Israelites were supposed to follow even before then, were exactly libertarian. It just wasn't the king who enforced them.

The original law given through Moses was all morality and highly metaphorical. When the scribes compiled it into a narrative form over time they also added their cultural and legal rules and tried to pass it off as one and the same. Most of the prophets and the writings are older than the torah, and you'll see a much different story in them more similar to the new testament, even after they were edited.

> "A woman shall not wear a man's garment, nor shall a man put on a woman's cloak, for whoever does these things is an abomination to the Lord your God." - Deuteronomy 22:5, (English Standard Version translation of the Bible)

How is this relevant?

body:
>Don't blindly believe everything labeled "Christian".

Certainly, one should not believe every political action to be genuine. But it's not like Christianity was never embraced by an authoritarian state. The Roman emperor Constantine I did so.

>How is this relevant?

I was pointing out the authoritarianism of Deuteronomy. Not only was it the law of the land, it was a rather strict law of the land. Quoting

>"If a man is found lying with the wife of another man, both of them shall die, the man who lay with the woman, and the woman. So you shall purge the evil from Israel." - Deuteronomy 22:22

would have served the same purpose.

Unless, as you say, the law has been edited and added to. Which is certainly news to me. How do we know what the original was again?

body:
> But it's not like Christianity was never embraced by an authoritarian state. The Roman emperor Constantine I did so.

Yeah, after changing it into Constantinianity.

> I was pointing out the authoritarianism of Deuteronomy. Not only was it the law of the land, it was a rather strict law of the land.

No indication is given as to its strictness, nor does it indicate whether it was a law of the land or a moral metaphor. But if it is a strict law it's interesting how no penalty is prescribed.

> "If a man is found lying with the wife of another man, both of them shall die, the man who lay with the woman, and the woman. So you shall purge the evil from Israel." - Deuteronomy 22:22

That's definitely part of the legal code. And most of that was invented by the Israelites, which is very obvious since God, the prophets, and Jesus all teach to *not* judge or condemn.

> Unless, as you say, the law has been edited and added to. Which is certainly news to me. How do we know what the original was again?

That's why it's repeatedly re-revealed. For instance, once to Abraham, again to Moses, again in Jeremiah 7-11, and again by Jesus. It is currently preserved in Luke 10:27, Mark 12:28-34, and Matthew 22:35-40.

That's definitely part of the legal code. And most of that was invented by the Israelites, which is very obvious since God, the prophets, and Jesus all teach to not judge or condemn.

Unless, as you say, the law has been edited and added to. Which is certainly news to me. How do we know what the original was again?

That's why it's repeatedly re-revealed. For instance, once to Abraham, again to Moses, again in Jeremiah 7-11, and again by Jesus. It is currently preserved in Luke 10:27, Mark 12:28-34, and Matthew 22:35-40.

parent.body:
I disagree. Which only reinforces that this opinion is indeed unpopular.

Conservatism has clear and visible roots to religion. And those roots run deep. The opposition to gay marriage and abortion for example clearly traces them there. Pre-Christian Europe wasn't exactly progressive, but it tolerated infanticide even after birth, not just before, and gay sex was the norm to a considerable degree.

Most, if not all, of what conservatism is trying to conserve has been given to us by religion.

Western traditional values aren't worth preserving just because they're traditional. They're worth preserving because they're good.

body:
I’d disagree. All values are relative. There are no “good” values. The only existentially good value is whatever allows you and yours to survive and last the longest over time. Everything else is dust.

For example, the thing most people would think would be a good value: a propensity towards technological advancement. And yet we see its effects: a zombified populace addicted to smartphones, easier to implement surveillance and censorship, accelerating centralization. And these are only short term effects. Long term, this value is the biggest threat to the continuation of the entire species. So how is it a good value?

Primitive people’s “barbaric” practices are only “barbaric” from another culture’s standpoint. Even things like human sacrifice. These are just cultural quirks, and none of them are worse than others. It’s much worse to try to impose one culture on another.
